coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The structure of PbOPbF2 glasses has been studied using molecular dynamics (MD). The existence of [OPb4] structural units is observed over the entire glass-forming range, in conformity with a model proposed earlier based on various structural investigations of this system. Various other features of the structural model are also supported by the MD calculations.

RAO1 SolidState and Structural Chemistry Unit, indian institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India Received 6 April 1988 The structure of PbO PbF5 glasses has been studied using molecular dynamics (MD). The existence of [OPb4] structural units is observed over the entire glass-forming range, in conformity with a model proposed earlier based on various structural investi- gations of this system. Various other features of the structural model are also supported by the MD calculations. 1. Introduction PbO is a typical covalent compound whereas PbF2 is highly ionic [1]. Glass formation has been estab- lished in the PbO PbF2 system over a wide range of compositions [2]. PbO PbF2 glasses are interesting from the point of view of the nature of bonding, since extreme (PbO-rich and PbF2-rich) compositions are either predominantly covalent or predominantly ionic; average ionicity of bonding varying continu- ously over the glass-forming region. The structure of these glasses has been investigated using a number of techniques such as X-ray diffraction, probe ion spec- troscopy XANES, EXAFS, etc. [2 5] in this labo- ratory. The structure has also been investigated using neutron scattering [6]. The important features re- vealed in these investigations are: (1) the glass structure is built up from [PbO2F4] motifs and (2) more importantly, oxygen is present in structural units of the type [OPb4 J in these glasses. [OPb4] units may be regarded as inverse analogues of [SiC4 I units in silica. The existence of these structural units was suggested to be crucial for glass formation, since they generate 0 Pb C chains. It was also shown from X-ray absorption near-edge studies that the sym- metry of the octahedral units [PbO2F4 } changes from C, through C2~ to D4h with increasing PbF2 content, * Communication No. 528 from the Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit. To whom correspondence should be addressed. or equivalent with increasing ionicity of bonding. The existence of [OPb4] units has only been indirectly justified since a direct and incontrovertible experi- mental verification is rather difficult. We therefore considered it interesting to simulate the structure of these glasses using molecular dynamics (MD). Since computer simulation by molecular dynamics using a (ionic) Born Mayer Huggins potential has been shown to be successful even in the case of silica and other glass systems [7 11] where bonding is mainly covalent, we were encouraged to use a similar po- tential in our MD studies. In this communication we report a MD simulation of the structure of PbO PbF2 glass which substantiates several features of the structural model proposed earlier. 2. Given in figs. la, lb, Ic, ld, le and 1 f are respectively the Pb 0, Pb F, 0 0, F F, 0- F and Pb Pb PDFs obtained in this study. In fig. 2 the 0 Pb PDF is given for three compositions along with the integrated areas under the peaks. The basic features of the lead oxyhalide glass structure relevant here are: (a) the presence of [OPb4] units as well as 0 Pb 0 chains in the struc- ture; (b) an increase in ionicity as the PbF2 content is increased, and (c) the presence of [PbO2F4) units in the glass compositions. The following features may be noted from the PDFs shown in fig. I vis a vis the features of the structural model: (1) Both Pb 0 and Pb F PDFs exhibit fairly nar- row first distance peaks. The Pb 0 PDF is partic- ularly narrow with the first peak at 2.2 A being consistent with its covalent nature although the model potential itself makes no provision for it. (2) Pb F distances are also sharply peaked at 2.55 A while the width of the peak suggests a moderate distribution in the Pb F first-neighbour distances. The PDF of Pb 0 suggests that beyond the first- neighbour oxygen, the distances of other oxygens are rather smeared out particularly in the high-PbO glasses. A rather broad peak emerges in the low-PbO glasses around 5.35 A, in spite of the low oxygen con- tent. These are precisely the features expected if ex- tensive Pb 0 Pb 0 links are present, since beyond the first shell the distances are dispersed. As the ion- icity increases, packing considerations force well de- fined geometries which emerge as discrete distances in the PDFs. (3) A reasonably well-defined second peak ap- pears in the Pb F PDF around 5.25 A whose defi- nition is again better in more ionic, low-PbO glasses. (4) 0 0 PDFs exhibit a split peak character with a rather broad distribution inbetween (fwhm of 1.5 and 2 A) peaked at 3.15 and 3.8 A. In low-PbO glasses the 3.15 A peak becomes very sharp but cor- responds to less than 20% of total oxygen present un- der the entire split peak suggesting very clearly that most oxygens are located 3.9 A away and not at 3.15 A. Initially the particles were assigned ran- dom coordinates in the computational cell and a Boltzmann distribution of Velocities corresponding to a temperature of 6000 K was assigned to them. A time step of 1 x 10 s was used. Samples were equilibrated at this initial temperature for about 2 ps. Later the samples were cooled to 3000, 1500, 750 and to 300 K, equilibrating for 2 ps at each temper- ature. Pair distribution functions (PDFs) were eol- lected over 2000 time steps at 300 K. It needed roughly 6 h of computer time for each equilibration. Our time steps and equilibrium times are compa- rable with other similar studies reported in the literature. (7) The first peak in the Pb Pb PDF exhibits a two-peak character (3.35 and 3.65 A) which nar- rows into a single dominant peak at 3.6 A with a fairly low fwhm in 5OPbO 5OPbF2 glass. Again this peak develops a two-peak character at 3.6 and 4.05 A in PbF2-rich glasses. PDFs also exhibit reasonably well- defined second peaks at twice the distance of the first peak. These features emerge due to the presence of [OPb4] tetrahedra and polyhedra centered on fluor- ide ions whose coordination number varies contin- uously. The narrow single peak character of 50PbO~50PbF2 glass indicates the formation of dominantly [OPb4 J and [FPb4] tetrahedra which, due to similar sizes ofF and 0, contribute to the same peak in the PDF. The situation changes in PbF2-rich glasses since the coordination number of fluorine falls and F Pb distances become larger due to the in- creased number of F ions and the relative decrease in the number of Pb atoms. Thus PDFs presented in fig. I amply demonstrate the key aspects of the struc- tural model developed for these glasses in earlier publications, in particular the one that glasses be- come more ionic as the PbF2 concentration in the glass increases. Even more crucial to the structural model of lead oxyhalide glasses is the assumption that Pb O Pb- type links are essential and hence lead atoms try to share available oxygens as completely as possible. In the process oxygen is present in [OPb4 I tetrahedra. Over the entire glass-form- ing region it shows that the number of lead atoms around oxygen is uniquely four. Molecular dynamics calculations can give crucial structural information which is otherwise not di- rectly available, such as for example the presence of [OPb4] tetrahedra in lead oxyhalide glasses. How- ever, we note that the Bom Mayer Huggins poten- tial used in the studies does not accurately represent the nature of interactions in this otherwise simple chemical system. But this potential does provide re- liable structural information even on highly cova- lently bonded systems such as Si02. We should, however, note that the total coordination number of lead, which the model suggested as six (two oxygens and four fluorines), is not born out as satisfactorily in these calculations (table 3). It is indeed quite un- satisfactory in the 80PbO~20PbF2 glass. Although this glass composition is a borderline case in terms of sta- bility, part of the reason could be that quenching rates in MD experiments are unphysically high and may perhaps not allow evolution of truly equilibrated structures relevant to the model. We thus conclude that several key aspects of the structural model of lead oxyhalide glasses are well substantiated using MD calculations. More detailed investigations are in progress.
